results.title: The General [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton Productions, United Artists Corporation, Joseph Schenck, Clyde Bruckman and Buster Keaton
results.brief_description: Keaton’s best, and arguably the greatest screen comedy ever made. Against a meticulously evoked Civil War background, Buster risks life, limb and love as he pursues his beloved railway engine, hijacked by Northern spies up to no good for the Southern cause. The result is everything one could wish for; witty, dramatic, visually stunning, full of subtle, delightful human insights, and constantly hilarious. Cast includes Buster Keaton and Marion Mack.

results.title: The Geisha boy
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Jerry Lewis and Frank Tashlin
results.brief_description: Gilbert Woolley (Jerry Lewis) is a third rate magician who has difficulty securing regular work in America when he is sent on a tour of Japan to entertain the troops. With his hapless and accident-prone ways Gilbert offends precious starlet Lois Livingston who is also on the bill, and raises the ire of the military with a series of embarrassing incidents. An aristocratic Japanese patron, who is impressed by Gilbert’s ability to amuse her depressed and reclusive young nephew Robert, saves Gilbert’s career from obscurity. Smitten with Gilbert, Robert causes an international diplomatic incident by following him back to the US. Even though it occasionally lapses into sentimental mawkishness, this film features much physical comedy as well as the usual mugging typical of Lewis’ schtick. “The Geisha boy” is one of director Tashlin’s eight collaborations with comedian Jerry Lewis (others include The Disorderly, Hollywood or bust, Who’s minding the store?).

results.title: The Gay divorcee
results.creator_credit: Pandro S. Berman and Mark Sandrich
results.brief_description: Adapted from the 1932 Cole Porter musical. The plot of “The Gay Divorcee”, rooted in mistaken identity is delightful. The script is sophisticated and bright and the cast is impeccable for comedy of this nature. Comparable to the best of Busby Berkeley and the most ingenious ballets of Gene Kelly, The Continental” dance routine is sufficient to turn “The Gay Divorcee into one of your most thrilling musical experiences. Stars Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.

results.title: The Gay deceivers
results.creator_credit: Fanfare Film Productions, Joe Solomon and Bruce Kessler
results.brief_description: Late sixties comedy about two young heterosexual men who pretend to be a gay couple in order to dodge the draft. Although the Army rejects the two, the recruiting officer questions their story and they are forced to move together into an all-gay L.A. apartment complex to add weight to their lie. Humour revolves around the comedy of misunderstandings that ensue involving the stereotypically ‘campy’ residents of the apartment complex. Though based on a homophobic premise, and aimed at a straight audience, the film is of interest as a naive camp curiosity and contains a few genuinely funny moments (and many unintentional ones). Along with “Boys in the Band” this was one of the only American 1960s mainstream films to feature homosexual characters. Cast includes Kevin Coughlin and Larry Casey.

results.title: The Gauntlet
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Malpaso Company, Robert Daley and Clint Eastwood
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood runs ‘The Gauntlet’ into an explosive piece of movie making that lives up to its title with a vengeance. He plays a burnt out Phoenix cop on an assignment to bring back from Las Vegas a ‘nothing witness for a nothing trial’ (Locke) which seems just another meaningless task in a meaningless life. Until the fireworks start! Trapped by treachery on both sides of the law, the two are forced through a deadly obstacle course of raging gunfire, blazing cars, swooping helicopters, murderous ambushes, crazed bikers and crooked police. With non-stop action and special effects that will blast you to the back of your seat, including a ferocious finale in which an armoured bus is shot to smithereens with more than 8,000 bullets (8000 bullets and none hit the tyres!). Leave the driving to Eastwood, sit back and enjoy the ride.

results.title: The Fury
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Frank Yablans and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s “The Fury” is a schizophrenic genre fusion of horror, action, political intrigue and supernatural thriller. De Palma revisits the realm of telekinesis which he first explored in Carrie (1976), giving it a kinetic spin this time around. Kirk Douglas plays Peter Sanza, a government agent who’s psychic son Robin (Andrew Stevens) is kidnapped while they are on holiday in the middle east. Fearing for his own life Peter goes into hiding and enlists the help of another Psychic (William Finley) to help him track down his son. Meanwhile Chicago teenager Gillian (Amy Irving) enrols into the Paragon Institute for Psychic research as she struggles to control her unruly telekinetic powers. However Gillian soon finds herself in danger as she begins to uncover a government plot involving her and Peter’s son Robin. Cast includes: John Cassavetes, Carrie Snodgress, Charles Durning, Fiona Lewis.

results.title: The Funeral
results.creator_credit: October Films, Mary Kane and Abel Ferrara
results.brief_description: Working from an original screenplay from his long time collaborator Nicholas St John, Abel Ferrara’s “The Funeral” sees the maverick director working in a more low key mode. That’s not to say of course that “The Funeral” doesn’t have Ferrara’s usual trademarks; seething violence, spiritual males and cathartic redemption. The film’s melancholic study of a crime family in crisis is set off by the murder of 22 year old Johnny Tempio (Vincent Gallo), shot dead in a movie theatre by a rival gang. His grief stricken brothers (Christopher Walken and Chris Penn) vow bloody revenge, while the women (Annabella Sciorra and Isabella Rossellini) of the family look for a more peaceful resolution. Ferrara is a master of transcending conventional genres as he proved with his bold reinvention of the vampire movie in The Addiction (1995) and his rabid cop drama Bad Lieutenant (1992). Again Ferrara manages to transcend the cliches of the gangster film as the bloody quest for revenge becomes an internal affair, leaving the mafia brothers to contemplate the nature of guilt and the futility of retribution. 1996 Venice Film Festival winner for Best Supporting Actor (Chris Penn) and the OCIC (Organisation Catholique Internationale du Cinema) Award for Abel Ferrara. Cast includes: Benicio del Toro, Gretchen Mol.

results.title: The Full Monty
results.creator_credit: Redwave Productions, Uberto Pasolini and Peter Cattaneo
results.brief_description:
Robert Carlyle stars as Gaz in this irreverent comedy set in the middle-England working class town of Sheffield. He is a jobless steel worker who dreams up an outrageous scheme to pull himself and his mates out of the personal and financial doldrums of long term unemployment. After seeing the money and adulation lauded upon the male exotic dance team The Chippendales by the females of the town, he rounds up willing and reticent participants for a review to be named the Full Monty. They are a collection of pigeon-chested, pot-bellied, heavy drinking, pale, wrinkly middle-aged strippers with one solitary gimmick - it all comes off!
Cast also includes: Tom Wilkinson, Mark Addy

results.title: The Fruits of passion = Les Fruits de la passion (E)
results.creator_credit: Argos Films, Terayama Productions, Anatole Dauman, Hiroko Govaers and Shuji Terayama
results.brief_description: A sexually explicit drama, “The Fruits of passion” is the sequel to “The Story of O”. Set in Hong Kong, 1920, the wealthy Sir Stephen is owner of a casino and living in delightful decadence, indulging in a multitude of amorous experiences. Stephen persuades his wife O to join him there and work in a brothel, as a means of demonstrating her love for him. Once there she is exposed to all manner of sexual peccadillos and perversions, frequently enacted whilst Stephen watches. Stephen embarks upon an affair with another woman, whilst O finds a new love of her own, challenging their marriage. “The Fruits of passion” is art-house fare that dabbles in soft porn, with a political backdrop. Although it toys with the themes of fidelity and eroticism, the film tends toward misogyny and spends an inordinate amount of time on the sexual proclivities of its protagonists but little on their mental states or emotional motivations. Based on the novel by Pauline Reage (aka Dominique Aury), who wrote the erotic classic, “The Story of O”. Warning - strong sexual content.
